purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 builds on resources defined in ISO 13584-20. A substantive capability for representation of expressions is provided by ISO 13584-20. This part extends that capability to meet additional requirements.

The expression_extensions_schema extends the usability of expressions by providing identifiers and relationships to other expressions or objects, as well as by identifing expressions that refer to instances of entity datatypes as defined in ISO 10303-11.

The logical_expressions_schema identifies expressions that return a logical result, where logical is defined as being true, false or unknown. This corresponds to the logical type defined in ISO 10303-11, the EXPRESS language reference manual. Logical expressions are specified when it is necessary to define tests that shall be applied in a given circumstance. Such tests may be used to determine a course of action or whether some aspect of product data is applicable in a given circumstance. It may not always be possible to fully evaluate a logical condition, in which case the result is "unknown".

introduction.p: This clause defines the requirements for the expression_extensions_schema. This clause contains resource constructs that allows expression representations to be utilized in practical ways.

fund_cons.p: Expressions are used by mathematical languages to construct formal sentences conveying semantics. Such sentences can often be interpreted by computer programs to carry out operations or deduce conclusions. The schemas in ISO 13584-20 defined EXPRESS entity datatype representations of the EXPRESS language itself. That specification made possible the representation of EXPRESS data with dynamic behavior.

There are, however, several practical application requirements that need to be supplemented. For example, there is a need for assigning a name label to a variable or function, such that it becomes possible to construct an EXPRESS function and store all elements of the function definition in a database defined in an EXPRESS schema. Also, the entity definitions and instances defined by an EXPRESS schema need to be treated as expressions so that they can be used in other expressions to construct further meaning or operations involving the entities. This schema provides the extension so that these types of utilization becomes possible.
The following requirements are supported by this schema:

ul.li: the identification of an expression by a label;
representing the definition of an EXPRESS entity type as an expression;
representing and referencing an instance of an EXPRESS entity type as a literal value;
the association of a variable with a defined function;
the association of an expression to an object of undetermined type;
the identification of a literal to its base expression type and the context of the value source;
the relationship between two expressions with an identified role.

schema.name: logical_expressions_schema
schema.introduction: This clause defines the requirements for the logical_expressions_schema. This schema allows expressions to be evaluated as true, false or unknown, as well as defining operator constructs based on the expression.

fund_cons.p: The following requirements are supported by this schema:

ul.li: an expression based on the logical datatype;
a degenerate Boolean expression as a result of restrictions placed on the logical expression;
specification of user defined comparison operators that return a logical value.
user defined logical comparisons expressed as a computer interpretable code and the identification of language type.
